headline: Owls Fall at Miami
content: CORAL GABLES, Fla. ‚Äì The Florida Atlantic women's basketball team fell in a hard-fought game 79-47 against the Miami Hurricanes on Thursday evening at the Watsco Center. The Owls move to 2-1 on the season, and the Hurricanes improve to 3-0. HOW IT HAPPENED Miami jumped to a 9-0 lead, holding Florida Atlantic scoreless for over three minutes in the first quarter. Ineivi Plata was able to put the Owls on the board with a layup, making the score 9-2. FAU was unable to close the gap throughout the first quarter, ending the period down 24-9. Jess Moors opened the scoring for Florida Atlantic in the second. Moor's points were followed by two Haley Walker layups and a Madi Gewirtz 3-pointer to cut Miami's lead to 11 with a score of 29-18. From there, the Hurricanes began to pull away, going on a 5-0 run. Michiyah Simmons stopped that run with her first points of the game late in the second quarter. The first half ended with the Hurricanes leading 42-23. Miami extended its lead to 23 at the beginning of the third quarter. Vivian Onugha stifled the Hurricane run with her first of the game to put the Owls back on the board, 46-25. Plata led Florida Atlantic in scoring in the third quarter with four points. Miami held a 26-point lead with the score standing at 61-35 going into the fourth quarter. The Owls scored first in the fourth from a Walker layup, 61-37. Grace Carstensen had her ninth point of the night shortly after knocking down her third 3-pointer. Miami slowly pulled away, extending its lead to 32 with four minutes to go. The Owls battled through the end of the fourth, ultimately ending the game 79-47. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we competed really well, but unfortunately, we didn't have our legs under us. The physicality of Miami's team kind of wore us down early. We had some open looks that typically fall for us, and they just weren't falling, and against a team like Miami, you really need those shots to fall. Proud of our effort, and I know we can learn a lot from this game." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Carstensen led the Owls with a team-high 14 points on the night. Gewirtz led the team on the glass with four boards. Moors had a team-leading three assists. The Owls led the Hurricanes at the line with 58 percent to 50 percent. Florida Atlantic led Miami in steals, 10-6. GALLERY Gallery: (11-13-2025) Florida Atlantic WBB at Miami (Nov. 13) UP NEXT The Owls will finish their three-game road trip in Mobile, Alabama, where they will face South Alabama on Thursday, Nov. 20, at 7 p.m. at the Mitchell Center on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

headline: Owls Complete the Day in NCAA South Regionals
content: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. - Florida Atlantic's men's and women's cross country teams competed in the 2025 NCAA South Regional Championships in Huntsville on Friday morning. The women ran a 6K to start the morning, finishing in 23rd place out of 28 teams on the day. On the men's side, they finished 26th on the morning after running a 10K. Anabell Reumann, Rosa ten Berg, Elyssa Toal, Leah Helms, Sophie Dethier, Madison Brown, and Reese Anderson competed for the Florida Atlantic women. Reumann crossed the finish line first for the Owls, finishing 112th overall. On the men's side, Paul Glick, Donovan Petty, Noah Highsmith, Nazayer Franco, and Nathan Webb ran for the Owls, finishing the day with 797 points. QUICK HITS Women Six out of the seven Owl runners recorded personal bests. Reumann etched her name in the record book with her performance today. She finished the morning with a 21:37.52 to put herself No. 9 in program history. Another personal best time for the Owls as ten Berg finished the morning with a time of 22:06.36 in her first NCAA Regional. Toal registered a 22:14.90, finishing 143rd overall. Helms finished 144th overall (22:15.21). Also in her first appearance in an NCAA regional, Dethier recorded a personal best with a 22:29.75 on the day, Brown (22:41.81) and Anderson (22:52.03) finished 163rd and 169th to close out the cross season. Men As a team, Florida Atlantic recorded 797 points on the day Glick got it all started for the Owls. He was the first one to cross the line with a 33:57.36. Behind him was Petty with a personal best, finishing 174th overall (34:25.22). Highsmith finished with a time of 34:47.89 (179th overall). The last two for FAU were Franco and Webb, making their first appearance at the NCAA South Regional Championships. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage of FAU cross country and track & field, follow us on social media. (@FAUXCTF)

headline: Owls Sweep UTSA on Senior Night
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic volleyball closed out regular season play on Friday, earning a straight-set sweep against the UTSA Roadrunners, 3-0 (26-24, 25-21, 25-21), on Senior Night inside Eleanor R. Baldwin Arena. The Owls close out the regular season at 19-10 and 10-6 in American play, while UTSA falls to 13-13 overall and 6-9 in conference play. HOW IT HAPPENED UTSA took the early advantage, leading 5-2, but a 4-0 FAU run gave the Owls their first lead of the match after a kill from Anna Hartman, 6-5. After a 10-10 tie, the Roadrunners retook the lead, holding a two-point advantage, 15-13, through the opening media break. UTSA extended its lead to 19-16, forcing the Owls to call their first timeout of the match, but following the break, the Owls scored three unanswered off a pair of Roadrunner errors and an ace from Erin Morrissey to tie the set at 19-19 and spark a UTSA timeout. The Roadrunners held set point at 24-22, but two kills from Hartman and one from Morrissey powered a set-ending 4-0 run as the Owls took the opening set, 26-24. The Owls fell into a hole early in the second, trailing 12-5 to open the set. Florida Atlantic battled back, outscoring the Roadrunners 10-3 to fight back and tie things up at 15-15 after a kill from Maggie Allred, sparking UTSA to call a timeout. The two squads battled back and forth through a tight 22-21 FAU lead, but the Owls recorded back-to-back kills from Libby Ashline, Olivia Hart, and Kayla Richardson to secure the second set, 25-21, and give FAU the two-set lead. Unlike the first two sets, Florida Atlantic came out firing in the third, opening the period on a 13-6 run. The Roadrunners battled back to cut the Owls' lead to three at 14-11, but FAU responded on a 4-1 run to extend its lead back to six, 18-12, and spark the Roadrunners to call a timeout. UTSA attempted to rally, battling back within two at 19-17 and 23-21, but the Owls capitalized on a pair of Roadrunner errors to close out the third, 25-21, and secure the straight-set sweep. STATS & NOTES Hartman led the way offensively for the Owls with a team-high 11 kills in the match. Emsley Venard finished with a team-best 21 assists. Isabelle Northam led the Owls' back row, recording a match-high 14 digs. Allred paced the Owls at the net, tallying a team-high four blocks in the win. As a team, the Owls led the Roadrunners in kills (41), assists (39), and service aces (6). FAU also held an advantage in side-out percentage, outpacing UTSA 61.8 percent to 54.1 percent. UP NEXT With the regular season in the books, the Owls will now prepare for the American Volleyball Tournament on Nov. 21-23 in Tampa, Florida, at the Yuengling Center. Tournament matchups and seeding will be finalized after the final regular season matches on Sunday. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic volleyball, follow @FAUVolleyball on X and Instagram, or like FAU Volleyball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Come Up Short Against Green Wave
content: NEW ORLEANS ‚Äì In its final road contest of the 2025 regular season, the Florida Atlantic football team fell to American Conference contender Tulane by a score of 35-24 on Saturday afternoon. The Owls (4-6, 3-4) were led by redshirt junior QB Caden Veltkamp, who set the individual single game program record in both completions (39) and attempts (57) while throwing for a season best 375 yards. He was assisted in the passing game by career best outings from redshirt junior WR Easton Messer (133 yards) and redshirt sophomore WR Asaad Waseem (11 receptions). VIDEO RECAP FIRST HALF Florida Atlantic's offense marched right into Green Wave (8-2, 5-1) territory on the opening drive, halted by an interception in the end zone. The defense forced consecutive three-and-outs before Tulane capitalized on a fumbled punt return and scored on the next play. The Owls put points on the board on the following possession, set up by Veltkamp finding Messer on a first-and-23 who turned a pass short of the sticks into a 50-yard gain. The drive led to a field goal from redshirt senior K Garrison Smith. After another Tulane touchdown to close the first quarter, Florida Atlantic responded with a 75-yard drive culminating in Veltkamp finding redshirt junior WR Jayshon Platt on fourth-and-goal for his third straight game with a receiving touchdown to narrow the gap to 14-10. The Green Wave scored once more to send the Owls to the locker room trailing 21-10. SECOND HALF FAU's defense stopped Tulane on two consecutive drives, first forcing a punt at midfield and then an interception by freshman DE Josh Roberts, before a touchdown late in third quarter extended the Green Wave lead to three scores. Not going down without a fight, Florida Atlantic put together another 75-yard scoring drive finishing with a score by sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton from one yard out to cut the deficit to 28-16. While Tulane found the end zone one more time with under five minutes to go, the Owls had one more drive left in them. Veltkamp connected with Messer for an 11-yard touchdown and Waseem for the ensuing two-point conversion. The onside kick came up short, leaving the 35-24 final. OFFENSE Veltkamp has thrown for 300+ passing yards in four games, most by an Owl quarterback in a single season since Chris Robison in 2019. Through 10 games in 2025, he is now eight completions away from setting the program's single-season record. Messer had his third 100+ yard game of the season, reaching 117 in the first half alone. He has hauled in 83 catches in 2025, now second all-time in program history for a single season. Platt is the first Florida Atlantic player to log a receiving touchdown in three straight games since LaJohntay Wester in 2022. Redshirt junior WR Dominique Henry recorded career highs in both receptions (six) and yards (78). DEFENSE Leading in tackles with a double-digit performance for the second week in a row was redshirt junior LB Leon Hart Jr. with 13, also notching 1.5 tackles for loss. Roberts' interception was the Owls' third of the season. Junior DE Deshaun Batiste and redshirt junior CJ Doggette Jr. joined forces for a sack. POSTGAME AUDIO Hagerty Family Head Football Coach Zach Kittley Sophomore RB Kaden Shields-Dutton PHOTO GALLERY Gallery: (11-15-2025) Florida Atlantic at Tulane UP NEXT Florida Atlantic returns home for the final two games of the 2025 regular season, first hosting Connecticut on Saturday, Nov. 22 at Flagler Credit Union Stadium. The afternoon will be one of commemoration and recognition for the program's 300th game. Kickoff is at 3 p.m. on ESPN+. FOLLOW ON SOCIAL Stay informed by reading FAUSports.com or through social media accounts @FAUFootball.

headline: Owls Crowned American Conference Champions
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer defeated FIU 3-2 on Saturday to capture the 2025 American Conference Postseason Tournament title. The victory is the program's second conference championship all-time and first since the 2007 Atlantic Soccer Championship. The start of Saturday's Championship Final was ominous for the Owls. FIU scored the opening goal just three minutes in after a mad scramble inside the six-yard box. In the midst of it, goalkeeper Alfred Mikkelsen took a kick to the face. The officials went to video review but ultimately upheld the call on the field, ruling it no foul. The FAU offense responded to tie the game in the 20th minute. Josh Ainge played a through ball to Mamadou Diarra. The two-time American Conference Offensive Player of the Year cut inside and connected on a thunderous strike past the FIU keeper. Four minutes later, the Owls grabbed the lead for the first time, and they would not relinquish it. Ethan Schumaker headed home a corner kick from Aboubacar Traore to send Florida Atlantic into halftime with a 2-1 lead. Diarra scored his second of the night in the 70th minute to double the lead. This time, it was Felipe Santos who played the striker into a dangerous area. Diarra found just enough space to fire off a left-footed strike from just outside the penalty area. The Owls led 3-1 with 20 minutes to go. FIU scored in the 80th minute, but the Panthers would get no closer. The Owls held on for a thrilling 3-2 victory. Diarra was named Offensive Player of the Tournament. Center back Fabrizio Cubbedu earned the Defensive Player of the Tournament award. Mamadou Diarra and the Florida Atlantic Owls poured it all out on the field and now they are champions üèÜüíô#BuiltToRise x #AmericanMSOC pic.twitter.com/2tDFVxthee ‚Äî The American (@American_Conf) November 16, 2025 The Owls have now earned an automatic berth in the NCAA National Championship First Round. They will learn their next opponent when the bracket is announced on Monday, November 17, at 1 p.m. For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Meet FIU in American Conference Championship
content: CHARLOTTE, N.C. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic men's soccer (11-3-2) squares off with FIU (7-8-3) in the American Conference Championship final on Saturday night. Kickoff is set for 6 p.m. in Charlotte, North Carolina. The winner receives an automatic bid to the NCAA National Tournament First Round. ABOUT THE OWLS The Owls' last appearance in a conference championship match was 2021, when they fell to No. 15 Kentucky 2-1 in overtime. The Owls are looking to earn their second conference tournament title (2007). Alfred Mikkelsen returned from a four-game absence on Wednesday night and recorded his sixth solo clean sheet of the season. Mikkelsen has tied the single season shutouts record... as a team, the Owls have already set a new record with eight shutouts. The Owls are looking to join the 2004 team with 12 wins in a season (second-most). 13 is the single season record set by the 1996 team. ABOUT THE PANTHERS FIU defeated Charlotte in penalty kicks on Wednesday. The Panthers finished fourth in the American in the regular season. SERIES HISTORY The Owls won the regular season matchup with FIU 2-0 on September 26. FIU eliminated the Owls in last season's American Conference Quarterfinals. WHAT'S NEXT The NCAA National Tournament selection show is set for Monday, November 17, at 1 p.m. First round matchups begin Thursday, November 20. FOLLOW US For complete coverage of FAU men's soccer, follow us on X and Instagram (@FAUMSoccer).

headline: Owls Sign Dynamic Guard Housey
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic women's basketball Head Coach LeAnn Freeland announced another big addition to the Owls' 2026 class with the signing of guard Jaelynn Housey on Friday. "Jaelynn Housey was the first player we identified as a priority when we took over the program in April," said Head Coach LeAnn Freeland. "Being a high-profile Florida player, our whole staff was aware of her abilities. Our goal is to keep the best Florida players at home, and Jaelynn is a great start. She's a big guard who can play multiple positions in our system. Her size, versatility, and skill set will pose matchup problems for smaller guards and bigger posts on both ends of the floor. She's a true winner and leader who has competed at a high level with Coach Hively at Nova High School and the Miami Suns AAU organization. Our coaching staff and players are excited that Jaelynn Housey is an Owl!" Housey, a south Florida native from Davie, Florida, joins the Owls from Nova High School. The Big 8 MVP and All-Broward honoree helped lead the Titans to two District Championships in 2024 and 2025. Entering her senior season at Nova, Housey has averaged 20.2 points, 6.1 rebounds, 4.1 steals, 3.9 assists, and 1.1 blocks per game. In addition to basketball, Housey also competes in flag football as a wide receiver and runs cross country. Off the court, Housey was named to the A/B honor roll and received a silver cord for accumulating over 200 hours of service. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook.

headline: Owls Fall at Miami

The first half ended with the Hurricanes leading 42-23. Miami extended its lead to 23 at the beginning of the third quarter. Vivian Onugha stifled the Hurricane run with her first of the game to put the Owls back on the board, 46-25. Plata led Florida Atlantic in scoring in the third quarter with four points. Miami held a 26-point lead with the score standing at 61-35 going into the fourth quarter. The Owls scored first in the fourth from a Walker layup, 61-37. Grace Carstensen had her ninth point of the night shortly after knocking down her third 3-pointer. Miami slowly pulled away, extending its lead to 32 with four minutes to go. The Owls battled through the end of the fourth, ultimately ending the game 79-47. HEAR FROM HEAD COACH LEANN FREELAND "I thought we competed really well, but unfortunately, we didn't have our legs under us. The physicality of Miami's team kind of wore us down early. We had some open looks that typically fall for us, and they just weren't falling, and against a team like Miami, you really need those shots to fall. Proud of our effort, and I know we can learn a lot from this game." NOTES AND TEAM STATS Carstensen led the Owls with a team-high 14 points on the night. Gewirtz led the team on the glass with four boards. Moors had a team-leading three assists. The Owls led the Hurricanes at the line with 58 percent to 50 percent. Florida Atlantic led Miami in steals, 10-6. GALLERY Gallery: (11-13-2025) Florida Atlantic WBB at Miami (Nov. 13) UP NEXT The Owls will finish their three-game road trip in Mobile, Alabama, where they will face South Alabama on Thursday, Nov. 20, at 7 p.m. at the Mitchell Center on ESPN+. FOLLOW THE OWLS To stay up to date with everything Florida Atlantic women's basketball, follow @FAUWBB_Hoops on X and @FAUWBB on Instagram, or like Florida Atlantic Women's Basketball on Facebook. Florida Atlantic's 2025-26 season is sponsored by Flagler Credit Union.

headline: Owls Set to Travel to Alabama for Regionals
content: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. ‚Äì Florida Atlantic's men's and women's cross country teams will travel to Huntsville for the 2025 NCAA Regionals on Friday, Nov.14 to conclude the 2025 fall season. The Owls are set to compete in the NCAA South Regionals, with the races airing on ESPN+. The women will run the 6K at 9:30 a.m., while the men will take on a 10K run beginning at 10:30 a.m. Florida Atlantic will compete at John Hunt Park. On the women's side, Reese Anderson, Madison Brown, Sophie Dethier, Leah Helms, Morgan Pennington, Anabell Reumann, Rosa ten Berg, and Elyssa Toal will compete in the 6k for the Owls. On the men's side, Nazayer Franco, Paul Glick, Samuel Henery, Noah Highsmith, Donovan Petty, and Nathan Webb will run the 10k. LAST TIME OUT Women (2025 American Championships) ten Berg finished with a time of 22:08.1 as the top Owl finisher for the second consecutive meet. Toal came in second for the Owls as she placed 53rd overall on the course with a time of 22:17.6. Seconds behind was Brown, running a 22:28.4. Reumann finished 64th overall with a 22:42.1. Helms finished 68th overall (22:52.4). Dethier (22:59.0) and Anderson (23:45.7) finished 70th and 81st overall in their first postseason run with the Owls. Men (2025 American Championships) As a team, Florida Atlantic recorded 360 points. Glick got it started for the Owls when he was the first to cross the finish line. Right behind was the freshman Petty with a time of 26:36.8. He recorded a career-best at the American Championships; last year. Back-to-back were Franco and Highsmith in their first appearance in an American Championship Webb placed 90th overall in his first postseason appearance. SEASON HIGHLIGHTS The Owls started off the season at the Keiser Invitational. Brown, Dethier, Anderson, and Pennington made their debut as Owls. On the men's side, Henery has competed very well in every race he has made an appearance. Webb, Franco, and Highsmith competed for the first time in an FAU uniform. FOLLOW THE OWLS For complete coverage of FAU cross country and track & field, follow us on social media. (@FAUXCTF)

headline: 2025 NFL Owls
content: BOCA RATON, Fla. ‚Äì Week 10 of the 2025 NFL season is in the books with five former Florida Atlantic Owls seeing action. Here's a rundown of how each performed during the 10th week (All gametimes listed below are Eastern): Active Owls (5) #0 Azeez Al-Shaair | LB | Houston Texans - For the fourth consecutive game, Al-Shaair played 100% of the team's defensive snaps. He notched a team-leading eight tackles and added a pass breakup in Houston's 36-29 comeback win over the Jacksonville Jaguars. Texans' Record: 4-5 Next Game: at Tennessee ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #88 Harrison Bryant | TE | Houston Texans - Bryant served as Houston's starting tight end in their major fourth quarter comeback victory. He saw the field for 17 snaps on offense and four on special teams in the 36-29 win. Texans' Record: 4-5 Next Game: at Tennessee ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) #84 Zaire Mitchell-Paden | TE | New Orleans Saints - Mitchell-Paden played a career high 26 snaps in New Orleans' 17-7 win over their NFC South rival Carolina Panthers. He logged his longest catch with a 14-yard grab with a first down. Saints' Record: 2-8 Next Game: The Saints will have their bye weekend before returning on Sunday, Nov. 23 to face the Atlanta Falcons. #42 James Pierre | CB | Pittsburgh Steelers - Pierre stepped up in a primetime performance against the Los Angeles Chargers on Sunday night football. In 48 snaps, he made five tackles and two key pass deflections. Pittsburgh ultimately fell to L.A. by a score of 25-10. Steelers' Record: 5-4 Next Game: vs. Cincinnati (and Hendrickson) ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) #26 Devin Singletary | RB | New York Giants - "Motor" made the longest play of the day for New York. On a third-and-one, he caught a pass behind the line of scrimmage and turned a potential tackle-for-loss into a 41-yard gain down the sideline to set up a Giants score. Singletary finished with 20 yards on eight rushes and 53 on three receptions as New York was defeated by the Chicago Bears in a 24-20 last-minute loss. Giants' Record: 2-8 Next Game: vs. Green Bay ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (FOX) On a Bye (1) #91 Trey Hendrickson | DE | Cincinnati Bengals Bengals' Record: 3-6 Next Game: at Pittsburgh (and Pierre) ‚Äì Sunday, 1 p.m. (CBS) Practice Squad (4) #58 Evan Anderson | DT | San Francisco 49ers #34 Greg Joseph | K | Las Vegas Raiders #62 Federico Maranges | C | Seattle Seahawks #73 Brandon Walton | OT | Carolina Panthers Check fausports.com each Thursday to see how each Owl did the previous week along with a preview of their respective team's next game.
